title: Jake Bradley Carlton, son of Carlton legend Craig Bradley signs with VFL affiliate Northern Blues | Fox Sports
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS THE Bradley name is back in navy blue. 
Jake Bradley, the son of Carlton legend Craig, signed with Carlton’s VFL affiliate Northern Blues earlier this month for the 2017 season. 
Bradley played in the Northern Blues’ development side last year and was on the radar during last year’s AFL national and rookie drafts. He played 10 TAC Cup matches with the Northern Knights. 
The 19-year-old averaged 17 disposals in the TAC Cup and could have gone to the Blues earlier but wanted to complete Year 12 first. He was granted permission to train with Carlton last June due to his spot at the Peter Dean Father-Son Academy.

His dad Craig holds the Blues’ all-time games record with 375 matches played over an incredible 17-year VFL/AFL career. Including his 98 games in the SANFL, Bradley is the all-time Australian football games record holder with 473 between 1981 and 2002. 
He won three Carlton best and fairests and two premierships, was named an All-Australian four times and skippered the Blues from 1998 to 2001. In his 375th and final AFL game Bradley received three Brownlow votes for collecting 30 disposals and a goal against Port Adelaide. Craig Bradley in action in 1997. Source: News Limited Bradley waves goodbye to his son Jake during his 350th AFL game in 2001. Source: News Limited Jake in 2001. Source: News Limited 
“It goes without saying about the name at the Carlton Football Club: he’ll play under our banner and we’re delighted to have young Jake,” Northern Blues GM Garry O’Sullivan said. 
“He’s certainly got his dad’s running attributes, he’s still developing but we feel he’s certainly got the attributes and the mindset to soak everything in that’s going on. 
“He’ll add to our group and has really shown a great desire to learn under Josh Fraser and the rest of the coaching staff.”
